title: Save Up on the Nothing Ear Wireless Buds with this Deal!
description: They come with all the essentials. The post Save Up on the Nothing Ear Wireless Buds with this Deal! appeared first on Phandroid.
author: Mike Viray
excerpt: They come with all the essentials.
text: If you’re after a unique-looking pair of wireless earbuds that combine looks, features and good-sounding audio, then you might want to consider the Nothing Ear buds. One of the latest audio products from Nothing, the new Ear model is on sale at the moment, going for as low as $115 from its usual retail price of $160. In terms of features, the new Nothing Ear comes with a custom 11 mm dynamic driver in addition to an improved dual chamber design from that of Ear (2), with two additional vents for better airflow. There’s also a battery which can provide up to 8.5 hours of playback on a single charge. It also features support for LHDC 5.0 and LDAC codec for Bluetooth streaming, and can reach up to 1 Mbps 24 bit/192 kHz with LHDC 5.0 (Low Latency High-Definition Audio Codec) and up to 990 kbps and frequencies up to 24 bit/96 kHz with LDAC. Note: this article may contain affiliate links that help support our authors and keep the Phandroid servers running. A writer and content creator with a love for tech and music, Mike is also an avid gamer as well. He and his wife are big fans of Mario Kart. html:
If you’re after a unique-looking pair of wireless earbuds that combine looks, features and good-sounding audio, then you might want to consider the Nothing Ear buds. One of the latest audio products from Nothing, the new Ear model is on sale at the moment, going for as low as $115 from its usual retail price of $160.

In terms of features, the new Nothing Ear comes with a custom 11 mm dynamic driver in addition to an improved dual chamber design from that of Ear (2), with two additional vents for better airflow. There’s also a battery which can provide up to 8.5 hours of playback on a single charge. It also features support for LHDC 5.0 and LDAC codec for Bluetooth streaming, and can reach up to 1 Mbps 24 bit/192 kHz with LHDC 5.0 (Low Latency High-Definition Audio Codec) and up to 990 kbps and frequencies up to 24 bit/96 kHz with LDAC.

Note: this article may contain affiliate links that help support our authors and keep the Phandroid servers running.

A writer and content creator with a love for tech and music, Mike is also an avid gamer as well. He and his wife are big fans of Mario Kart.
